intro: Mentha japonica, commonly known as Japanese mint, is a perennial herb native to East Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, serrated leaves that emit a strong mint scent when crushed. Its flowers are small, tubular, and usually pink or purple, clustered in whorls along the stem. Japanese mint is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb due to its refreshing aroma and cooling properties.
